Houston.

I didn't notice it before, bur equation (4,2) is wrong.  The a5 term  
should be divided by T, and there should be a '+' sign between the  
quadratic and cubic terms. This problem only affects the documentation,  
however - it is implemented correctly in the code. The coefficients in  
a 'cti' NASA entry should be identical to those in a Chemkin-style  
thermo database entry. Sorry for the confusion.

Dave


On Thursday, October 23, 2003, at 05:04 AM, Houston Miller wrote:

> Hi Dave,
>
>
>
> We have been playing with the opposed diffusion flame code (Very
> impressive!) and wish to apply it to some methane flame-doping  
> experiments
> that we are doing.  For this, we need to add several new species for  
> which
> thermo and transport data is fleeting.  I am using  group additivity   
> data
> to estimate thermo properties.  I am now at the point of trying to add  
> NASA
> coefficients into the "cti" file we are creating.  The problem is that  
> I am
> a bit confused about the form for the enthalpy that goes into the  
> file.  The
> documentation (cti.pdf, Eqn. 4.2) suggests a slightly different form  
> than
> the old Chemkin-II approach.  (In particular, should the sixth  
> coefficient
> be divided by temperature.) I have started to reverse engineer by  
> running
> through the same process with a known molecule, but I thought it might  
> be
> both more efficient to ask you, and clarify this for others as well.
>
>
